Title: Association between maternal exposure to perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Authors: Zhuoma Deji, Peng Liu, Xin Wang, Xin Zhang, Yuehua Luo, Zhenzhen Huang
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "a systematic review and meta-analysis of twenty-one published articles was conducted to explore the association between maternal exposure to PFASs and adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage, stillbirth and preterm birth."
  - "The systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the general principles recommended in the Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology consensus statement and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) criteria"
  - "The first meta-analysis on maternal PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes was performed."
  - "this meta-analysis work based on twenty-one studies was intended to examine possible relationships between PFASs exposure in maternal period and three adverse pregnancy outcomes."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The paper explicitly states that it is the "first meta-analysis on maternal PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes," indicating that it is a meta-analysis.
- The authors describe their work as a "systematic review and meta-analysis," which confirms the type of review.
- The paper follows the PRISMA criteria, which is a standard for systematic reviews and meta-analyses, further supporting the claim that it is a systematic review and meta-analysis.

Title: ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANT EXPOSURES AND PRETERM BIRTH: A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW
Authors: Kelly K Ferguson, Marie S O'neill, John D Meeker
Venue: Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health. Part B, Critical Reviews
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "This is a comprehensive review of all known studies published from 1992 through August 2012 linking maternal exposure to environmental chemicals during pregnancy with preterm birth."
  - "In conclusion, no consistent evidence was found for positive associations between individual chemical exposures and preterm birth. By identifying limitations and addressing the gaps that may have impeded the ability to identify true associations thus far, this review can guide future epidemiologic studies of environmental exposures and preterm birth."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The paper explicitly states that it is a "comprehensive review" of studies linking environmental chemical exposures to preterm birth. This indicates that the authors are conducting a broad and thorough examination of existing literature on the topic.
- The term "comprehensive review" suggests that the authors are not limiting their analysis to a specific subset of studies or using a specific statistical method to combine results, which would be characteristic of a meta-analysis.
- The focus on summarizing and critiquing existing studies rather than statistically combining their results further supports the classification as a comprehensive review rather than a meta-analysis.

Title: Early-Life Exposure to Per-and Poly-Fluorinated Alkyl Substances and Growth, Adiposity, and Puberty in Children: A Systematic Review
Authors: Yun Jeong Lee, Hae Woon, Hwa Young Kim, Yoon-Jung Choi, Young Ah Lee, Alberto Mantovani
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim: - "This systematic review was reported according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines (14)."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The authors explicitly state that their review is a "systematic review," as indicated by the phrase "This systematic review was reported according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines."
- The mention of PRISMA guidelines further supports that the review is systematic, as PRISMA is a standard for reporting systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

Title: Human exposure pathways to poly-and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) from indoor media: A systematic review
Authors: Nicole M Deluca, Jeffrey M Minucci, Ashley Mullikin, Rachel Slover, Elaine A Cohen Hubal, Adrian Covaci, B S T R A C T
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "This systematic review (SR) synthesizes evidence for exposure from indoor residential pathways to inform understanding of variability in serum PFAS levels in the general population from sources other than drinking water and diet."
  - "This systematic review adapted existing tools and methodologies to investigate the importance of PFAS exposure pathways from indoor and residential media including consumer products, household articles, cleaning products, personal care products, and indoor air and dust."
  - "This systematic review used a modified version of the risk of bias tool for epidemiology studies described in EPA's Systematic Review Protocol for the PFBA, PFHxA, PFHxS, PFNA, and PFDA IRIS Assessments (U.S. EPA, 2019) to evaluate each study."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The paper explicitly states that it is a "systematic review" multiple times, indicating that the authors claim their review to be a systematic review.
- The use of specific methodologies and tools, such as a modified risk of bias tool and adherence to a systematic review protocol, further supports the classification as a systematic review.
- The focus on synthesizing evidence from various studies to understand exposure pathways aligns with the characteristics of a systematic review.

Title: Legacy and emerging pollutants in Latin America: A critical review of occurrence and levels in environmental and food samples
Authors: Cristina Marília,  Oliveira Souza, Bruno Alves Rocha, Joseph A Adeyemi, Martí Nadal, José Luis Domingo, Fernando Barbosa, Damià Barceló
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "The current review intends to cover the literature data on the observed levels of the most representative legacy and EPs in several environmental and food samples."
  - "For this review, up to 350 publications were identified in the initial search. Among them, only 176 studies were selected and included in this critical review (Fig. 1"
  - "this review compiles the current knowledge of the levels of different classes of EPs and legacy pollutants in food and environmental matrices (soil, sediment, water, and air) of the LA region."
  - "The selection of articles for this review was carried out according to the following relevant points: i) a complete description of the matrices, like geographical localization, collection, and storage of samples; ii) an adequate number of analyzed samples, according to the type of the sample (the amount depends on the sample type); iii) analytical methods described with appropriate quality control (QA/QC) methodology."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The paper is described as a "review" multiple times, indicating that it is a review article.
- The authors mention that the review "compiles the current knowledge" and "covers the literature data," which suggests a comprehensive review of existing literature.
- The selection criteria for articles included in the review are detailed, indicating a systematic approach to selecting studies.
- The review includes a large number of studies (176) selected from a broader search, which is typical of a systematic review.
- The use of terms like "critical review" suggests that the authors are providing a detailed and critical analysis of the literature.

Title: Organic Contaminants in Chinese Sewage Sludge: A Meta-Analysis of the Literature of the Past 30 Years
Authors: Xiang-Zhou Meng, Arjun K Venkatesan, Yi-Lin Ni, Joshua C Steele, Ling-Ling Wu, Anders Bignert, Åke Bergman, Rolf U Halden
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "In this study, we present the first systematic review and a meta-analysis of OCs in Chinese sludge based on the literature published over the past 30 years."
  - "Using literature from the past 30 years (N = 159), we conducted a meta-analysis of organic contaminants (OCs) in Chinese sludge."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The paper explicitly states that it is a "meta-analysis" of organic contaminants in Chinese sludge, indicating that it is a quantitative review that synthesizes data from multiple studies.
- The authors also describe their work as a "systematic review," which suggests a comprehensive and structured approach to reviewing the literature.
- The combination of these terms suggests that the review type claimed is a "meta-analysis" and "systematic review."

Title: Perfluoroalkyl substances and lipid concentrations in the blood: A systematic review of epidemiological studies
Authors: Soon Hoe Ho, Stacy Xin, Hui Soh, Min Xian Wang, Janet Ong, Annabel Seah, Yvonne Wong, Zhanxiong Fang, Shuzhen Sim, Jue Tao Lim, C L E I N F O, Adrian Covaci
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "This systematic review aims to assess PFAS associations with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL), total cholesterol (TC) and total triglyceride (TG) concentrations in human populations."
  - "In this systematic review, we assessed the associations between a comprehensive variety of PFAS and the concentrations of LDL, HDL, TC, and TG in human serum, plasma or whole blood as primary outcomes, supplemented with assessments of the associations between PFAS and several lipid-related health outcomes as proxy measures for lipid concentrations."
  - "This review has several strengths. Firstly, we placed no restrictions on the type of PFAS addressed, allowing us to assess the frequency with which different PFAS were studied and where research gaps exist."
  - "We considered the suitability of performing a meta-analysis of the findings but found that to be unfeasible."
  - "Instead, we chose to synthesise the various effect sizes by vote counting the positive and negative effect directions (McKenzie and Brennan, 2022)."
  - "In conclusion, this is one of the few systematic reviews to comprehensively assess the effect of exposure to a variety of PFAS on LDL, HDL, TC and TG concentrations in human populations."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The paper is explicitly described as a "systematic review" multiple times throughout the text.
- The authors mention that they considered performing a meta-analysis but decided against it due to the heterogeneity of the data, instead opting for a vote counting method.
- The paper is focused on assessing associations between PFAS and lipid concentrations, which aligns with the characteristics of a systematic review.
- The authors do not claim to have conducted a meta-analysis; instead, they emphasize the systematic review nature of their work.

Title: The Association between ADHD and Environmental Chemicals-A Scoping Review
Authors: Sonja Moore, Laura Paalan, Lisa Melym, Andromachi Katsonouri, Marike Kolossa-Gehring, Hanna Tolonen
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "The focus of this scoping review was only on those selected as the priority substances of the HBM4EU project."
  - "This scoping review aims to summarize known or possible associations between ADHD and environmental exposures to substances selected as priority chemicals of the European Human Biomonitoring Initiative (HBM4EU)."
  - "The literature searches were not conducted in a manner that fulfilled the criteria of a systematic review. This is a scoping literature review [14], which summarizes epidemiological studies on the associations of ADHD and HBM4EU priority substances, or their possible associations, which justify further research."
  - "The starting point for the current review was the list of priority chemicals of the HBM4EU project (https://www.hbm4eu.eu/) (accessed on 13 January 2022) [12]. Reviews and meta-analyses on the association of these chemicals with ADHD were compiled in the current paper."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
- The authors explicitly state that their review is a "scoping review," which is a type of review that aims to identify and summarize existing research on a particular topic without necessarily conducting a comprehensive systematic review.
- The paper is described as a "scoping literature review," which further supports the classification as a scoping review.
- The authors mention that the literature searches did not meet the criteria for a systematic review, reinforcing the notion that this is a scoping review rather than a systematic review or meta-analysis.
